dialogues.text: Absolute darkness. Then, a single narrow spotlight goes o revealing a RINGMASTER, with top hat, his back to us, alo With his head bowed, the top hat casts his face in shadow As the MUSIC picks up, he sings in a hushed, dramatic voi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ringmaster looks the other way -- a new spotlight hit beautiful TIGHTROPE WALKER, way up high, seemingly walkin air through the vast darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cannon FIRES -- sending a HUMAN CANNONBALL flying throu the darkness, spotlight following, til he lands in a nett

dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: He turns left -- roving SPOTLIGHTS find glimpses of DARED horse riders circling a circus ring, doing amazing stunts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns right -- SPOTLIGHTS catch ACROBATS in a circus r doing an insane teeter-board act. Bodies fly through the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the SONG ESCALATES, two FIRE BREATHERS step up and... .--BLOW huge COLUMNS OF FIRE in the air over Barnum’s hea Suddenly, all the FOOTLIGHTS go on, revealing a full-thro 3-ring Circus in full motion all around Barnum -- elephan doing handstands; lion tamers cracking whips; jugglers tossing rings across the room; horses dancing on two hoov Barnum strides thru it all -- grinning; happy -- and sing his heart out -- welcoming us to his world: The Big Top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His SONG is joined by group of ODDITIES, whom we will get know in due time, both in their strangeness and high-spir humanity. The gentle O’CLANCY THE IRISH GIANT, the talles man in the world. LETTIE THE BEARDED LADY; CHANG AND ENG, the legendary Siamese twins... One by one, they join in, walking with Barnum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We become aware of a CROWD outside the three rings.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen! Cads and crooks! Children of all ages! Welcome to another world! Where beauty walks with danger! Where the impossible is commonplace! And where nothing is quite what you expect...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnum concludes by throwing his head back, arms wide...

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Welcome... To the Greatest Show on Earth! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 3.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The crowd, in the dim light outside the rings, goes wild. Now ALL the PERFORMERS join in, singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Performers sing, Barnum takes in CHILDREN’S FACES the crowd, their awe; their wonder; their delight. Then Barnum turns to watch the show with them. SOUND FADE as Barnum, in a brief moment, sings to himself about the road it took to get here. In counterpoint to the Performe exuberant singing, Barnum’s words are reflective and wist

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARNUM is yanked out of his reverie by the Performers. Jolted back to reality, he joins their spirited song agai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the SONG reaches a climax, abruptly ALL THE LIGHTS go leaving Barnum again alone in the SPOTLIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, tonight we offer you a story. A parable, if you will. Of a man caught between the real world and the world of his dreams. A world where anything is possible, if you only believe... As the CAMERA circles him, Barnum sings the last few line

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the song ends, we PUSH IN to a close-up of BARNUM, silhouetted against the blinding lights and MATCH CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE. A close-up of YOUNG BARNUM (10) silhouetted agai the sun. Someone else is with him, but hard to see. We don’t know where we are. Young Barnum speaks gently.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: All you have to do is jump.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARITY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: That’s what makes it fun! * WIDER -- Young Barnum and Young Charity (also 10), stand the limb of a giant old tree that reaches out over the wa She wears a white party dress. He is in scuffed work clot It’s a 20 foot drop to the water -- no small feat.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARITY
dialogues.text: I shouldn't be doing this. *

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: That also makes it fun! *

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARITY
dialogues.text: You always make me do crazy things! *

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: It’s like you're flying! For one second, * you feel free! * She looks down a moment, then pulls back. *

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARITY
dialogues.text: I can’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: Of course you can! You just have to take that first step... She half-smiles, still scared. Nods bravely -- let’s do i YOUNG BARNUM (CONT’D) Ready? One, two, three...! They jump. And fall, side-by-side... SPLASH! They surface She is laughing, delighted. She just became a braver pers

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARITY
dialogues.text: Let's do that again! And again, and again, and again! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 5.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He grins -- dazzled by her delight. They swim to the shor and climb steps up onto a lawn -- laughing, high-spirited

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: I saw a sea nymph underwater! *

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARITY
dialogues.text: You did not!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: She was wearing a white dress! She laughs. He drinks in her laughter. Behind them, we SE grounds of a massive, old-money Connecticut estate.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HALLETT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Charity! They turn. MR. HALLETT, patrician and stern, steps forwar glaring balefully. Behind him, a grounds-keeper with a ra PHILO BARNUM (40s), in work clothes, looks on worriedly. Charity quickly bows her head -- becoming docile, obedien

dialogues.speaker: MR. HALLETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this how we have taught you to behave? Like a person of no breeding? Come here! * Look at your dress! How many times have * I told you not to trouble the help! * She walks to her father, not looking at Young Barnum.

dialogues.speaker: PHILO
dialogues.text: It’s the boy’s fault, sir. I’m sorry. * He’s a bit touched in the head, you know. * Come on, son. There’s work to do.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HALLETT
dialogues.text: You've done quite enough today, Mr. Barnum. There’s that for your troubles. He hands over a nickel. Philo bows obsequiously.

dialogues.speaker: PHILO
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Apologies again. * Mr. Hallet turns, walks back to his estate. Charity follo dutifully. Barnum watches. Then she turns, and, behind he father’s back, smiles at him. Young Barnum is thunderstru This smile, a beacon of joy, will become his North Star. Philo -- seeing his son’s love-struck gaze -- swats his h

dialogues.speaker: PHILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? Let’s get home. *  The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing quaint here, the austere room reflects a hardscra Yankee life. The family sits at the table as Barnum’s fou younger SIBLINGS (ages 3 to 7) are served thin soup by th mother IRENE. Barnum is telling them stories, and they ar giggling and enthralled. Philo listens in impatient silen

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: ..--And when I get to India, I shall ride an elephant! And capture a tiger!

dialogues.speaker: IRENE
dialogues.text: And what will you do with a tiger?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: I‘ll give my tiger as a gift to the Raj. And everyone will want to come see it! And the Raj will become my best friend, and he will offer me half his kingdom...

dialogues.speaker: PHILO BARNUM
dialogues.text: Phineas.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: ..-And I shall say, “No, thank you, sir!” Philo SLAMS his hand on the table. Everyone jumps. Silenc

dialogues.speaker: PHILO BARNUM
dialogues.text: As of Monday, you’1l join me on the farm.

dialogues.speaker: IRENE
dialogues.text: What about his schooling?

dialogues.speaker: PHILO BARNUM
dialogues.text: A waste of time. His place is in the fields.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: But father...! Philo silences him with a sharp look. It hurts to say:

dialogues.speaker: PHILO BARNUM
dialogues.text: You can dream all you want, son. It won’t put food on the table. Barnum stares. He gets up, leaves the table, and exits.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED

dialogues.text: Young Barnum sits on a beach -- his father’s words echoin his head. He looks up to see young Charity approaching.

dialogues.text: How did you get out?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARITY
dialogues.text: I climbed out the window once father got into his Port. She sits down next to him. She is downcast as well. *

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: Were you scolded?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARITY
dialogues.text: Were you? They share a look -- they both were. They turn to the sun sad and pensive. Then Barnum picks up a piece of driftwoo

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: Do you know what this is? She can’t help but smile, knowing that a story is coming. YOUNG BARNUM (CONT’D) Look carefully. You see? * (he turns it in his hand) It’s the fossil of a Mermaid from * Atlantis. She looks. Amazingly, the driftwood has a mermaid-like sh YOUNG BARNUM (CONT’D) It’s a priceless treasure. * He gives it to her. She smiles, but is suddenly teary-eye

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARITY
dialogues.text: I’m going to miss you. He turns to her -- what does that mean? She turns to him. YOUNG CHARITY (CONT’D) Father is sending me to finishing school. *

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: When will I see you again? She shakes her head -- never. He is caught off guard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 8.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARITY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what my future will be. Father says I am to be a lady, but... It’s all so dull when you’re not there. He looks at her. He has one chance to not lose her foreve

dialogues.text: I can see my future. And yours too.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CHARITY
dialogues.text: No, you can’t.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: I can. I/’11 show you... MUSIC starts under, a simple piano theme, both sweet and

dialogues.text: Barnum leads Charity up the front walk of a huge neoclass mansion that has fallen into disrepair.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BARNUM
dialogues.text: It’s okay. No one lives here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark, lit only by the moon. Barnum leads Charity through the rooms. As he sings about a world he envisions we see trophy animals, oriental antiques, and curiosities

dialogues.text: A WORLD THAT’S WAITING UP FOR ME THAT

He lights a CANDLE. The SHADOW of the lion comes to life, roaring. Around the room, SHADOWS flicker with GLIMPSES o tumblers, acrobats, trapeze artists, elephants, and clown YOUNG BARNUM (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE DOOR
dialogues.text: THROUGH WHERE NO ONE’S BEEN BEFORE BUT IT

dialogues.speaker: FEELS LIKE HOME

dialogues.text: Philo Barnum’s funeral in a run-down cemetery. Just the PRIEST and Barnum’s Mother and four Young Siblings. Barnu gazes at the family that’s dependent on him now -- wishin there were some way to take their misery away:

dialogues.speaker: A VISION OF THE ONE I SEE
dialogues.text: Behind him, a figure approaches. He turns. It’s Charity, out of place in this humble setting. She meets his eyes, steps up beside Barnum, discreetly holds his hand. * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: INT./EXT. HALLET’S HOUSE - BETHEL, CONNECTICUT - DAY 15 MUSIC continues under. Barnum strides up the front walk o the Hallet’s grand house -- scared but determined. He’s a adult now, a younger version of the man we first met. As he steps onto the porch, the door is pulled open. Mr Hallet stands in the doorway, scowling, blocking his way. Barnum takes off his hat -- humbly dressed, but respectfu

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Mr. Hallet, I know how I look to you, but you have my word, I will take care of your daughter. And one day, I’1l buy her a house like this one --

dialogues.speaker: MR. HALLETT
dialogues.text: With what?! You have no education, no prospects... No common sense! * Barnum is hurt but not surprised. He sees something over Hallet’s shoulder. Mr. Hallet turns to look. Charity, 18, carries a suitcase down the grand staircase to the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HALLETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charity! If you walk out that door now, I am cutting you off from everything. * Charity summons up her strength... And walks past him. Sh pauses to kiss her distraught mother on the cheek. *

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Goodbye, mother. * She steps onto the porch, smiles up at Barnum. He takes h suitcase. Charity slips her arm thru his, and they run of

dialogues.text: Barnum, carrying Charity’s suitcase, leads her through a railroad tunnel. MUSIC continues under.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Where are you taking me?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Just a little further. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 11.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He comes to a stop in the middle of the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now. What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Darkness.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I see the future. OUR future.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: And what does our future hold, Mr. Barnum? He leans in and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Magic. And just then the TRAIN arrives above them, light and ste filling the tunnel with wonder.

dialogues.text: WIDER -- His is one desk in a vast office of Accountants, crammed in tidy rows. A CACOPHONY of adding machines. It’ as far from his youthful dreams as he could have imagined

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BOSS, 60s and well-dressed, walks out and waves his arm Gradually, everyone stops working. The room goes silent.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I regret to say you’re all * dismissed. Company’s gone bankrupt. *

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Bankrupt? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: BOSS
dialogues.text: Typhoon. All our trading ships are at the * bottom of the South China Seas. Better luck with your next job. If you find one. He claps Barnum’s shoulder, walks off. Barnum slumps back gut-punched. He frowns, eyes darting, thinking fiercely. Everyone else gets up and begins to filter out of the roo A HUBBUB of MURMURS. Only Barnum remains seated. * He sees a pencil holder (a metal can dotted with holes) o his desk. Reaches over, dumps the pencils out. Holds it u

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Would you mind if I take this home? *

dialogues.speaker: BOSS
dialogues.text: Take anything you can carry. It’s all * junk now. * The Boss departs, leaving Barnum alone. He turns and scan the office, mind racing. He frowns, frowns... And smiles. INT. BARNUM’S TENEMENT - NIGHT 17 Barnum enters, exhausted from work. He carries the pencil holder, and several large files. It’s a cramped tenement. Barnum and Charity are in their 30s now. His daughters, CAROLINE, 7, and HELEN, 3, greet him with cries of happin (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 18 19 20 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 13.

Charity blows out a lantern. * Suddenly, the room is only lit by a hundred points of lig emitted from holes. Barnum spins the pencil holder, and t points of light spin around the room. The Girls are dazzl

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, Caroline.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: It’s a wishing machine. Built by the * King of Siam. Stolen by pirates. Lost * in a great storm. It’s the only one in * the whole world. You tell it all your * wishes and it holds them safe.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: My wish is to marry Santa Claus!

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: That’s a good wish!

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: I wish for a pair of ballet slippers, so I can be a ballerina. Barnum smiles, but he’s flat broke. It rips his guts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC continues as Barnum sits on the ledge, flipping thr pile of BILLS, many stamped OVERDUE. Barnum sings, wistfu

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: ‘CAUSE EV‘RY NIGHT I LIE IN BED *

dialogues.speaker: THE BRIGHTEST COLORS FILL MY HEAD
dialogues.text: A MILLION DREAMS ARE KEEPIN’ ME AWAKE * Charity steps out to find Barnum gazing out at the lighte skyline. She kisses the back of his head, sits beside him Barnum shakes his head and looks at the bills in his hand (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 14.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ballet slippers. Can’t even afford that. I work all day to make rich men richer. And every time I have an idea to do something on my own, I lose our savings.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: At least there wasn’t much to lose... She smiles, but he can’t return it. She rubs his back. *

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see things other people don’t. * That’s what I love about you. *

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) * When I think of the life you gave up... *

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: I didn’t give it up. You saved me from * it. * Finally, he looks at her -- quietly admitting the hard tr

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: This isn’t the life I promised you. I know that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: I have everything I want right here with you.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: What about that house we were going to fill -- with magic and wonder?

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: What do you call those two girls downstairs? He looks at his wife, finally smiles. She’s gotten throug Charity leans against his shoulder. Delicately, he ventur

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Charity... I’ve had another idea. She turns -- intrigued and worried. Now what? *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A window sign that reads: LOTTERY TICKETS INSID (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 22 23 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 15.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There is a line out the door, waiting to buy. Barnum, as barker, seems to really believe his own pitch -- there’s urgent sense of trying to save people from a humdrum life Caroline stands nearby, handing out lottery fliers.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Come one, come all! Step right up! This is a chance to live your dreams! Everyone has an equal shot! All you need is a ticket! Someone’s going to go home rich! Why not you?! Why not buy a ticket?! Why not buy ten?! Suddenly, a police WHISTLE. A SQUADRON of COPS swarms int the store. CUSTOMERS in line react with catcalls and BOOS

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Sorry, Barnum. The State of New York will never condone lottery gambling.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: A lottery isn’t gambling! It’s hundreds of people coming together with a dream --

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Yeah -- while you skim twenty percent!

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Twenty? I skim thirty at least! Another COP pulls down the Lottery sign and rips it up.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. I just paid two dollars for that! As the COPS dismantle Barnum’s makeshift lottery stand, h turns to see Caroline watching him. Barnum smiles bravely

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowded shopping street. Barnum walks in the crowd, dee frustrated by this setback. Caroline tags along with him. He stops on the curb, as a HORSE-DRAWN WAGON drives past.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Why'd they close it down?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Because they can’t see! And if they can't see it, it doesn’t exist! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 24 25 26 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 16.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. * As they cross the street, Barnum stops, searching for the right words -- beyond frustrated. Up the street, a MAN st into the path of the HORSE-DRAWN WAGON. Its DRIVER yanks horse’s reins, causing the wagon to JACKKNIFE. Barnum tur Suddenly: SEVERAL HUNDRED BRIGHTLY-COLORED BALLS... .-+.-Spill out onto the street, bouncing and rolling past in every direction. It’s a wondrous moment. They’re right in the center of it. All other activity stops as CHILDREN and ADULTS, gather up the balls, tossing them back and fo Barnum watches as the ashen street is transformed into a festive tempest of color and joy. Barnum leans in, pointi

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Look! *

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: They're dancing...! *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEDESTRIANS -- Avoiding the balls, trying to keep their * balance -- seem to mimic a choreographed circus routine. brief explosion of joy, color, movement, mirth, excitemen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnum is transfixed by his sudden glimpse. To Caroline:

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: You see? When the unexpected happens, everything is possible! The rules go out the window! Life becomes joyous! Caroline nods, sharing his excitement. Then, gradually, street activity returns to normal. Barnum shakes his head

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I could capture that...! And as he watches wistfully, a last ball rolls across the street and comes to a stop in front of a derelict three-s building with a FORECLOSURE NOTICE on the front door. Barnum turns his eyes up at the building. An idea forming

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 26
dialogues.text: 27 28 29 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnum sits opposite a BANK MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnum, this venture you propose is risky, if not downright bizarre. The bank is going to need substantial collateral -- Barnum puts a full set of legal documents on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I own the deed and title to every trading vessel in this flotilla. The Banker looks at the documents, then at Barnum, impres

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: I see. And where are these ships now?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: (all-too-literally true: ) In the South China Seas.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: (nods, approving) Ah. Well, then! What do you plan to call this... scheme of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnum shows his family his new building, spruced up with flags and colorful posters. A sign introduces ‘BARNUM’'S AMERICAN MUSEUM OF CURIOSITIES.’ Caroline reads it, puzzl

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Barnum’s American Museum of Curiosities.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: What kind of museum is it, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: It’s a place to be transported! To let your imagination soar! To see things you never in your life thought you’d see!

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: What sort of things? INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - DAY 29 THWACK! A GUILLOTINE BLADE comes down, cutting off Marie Antoinette’s head. Helen covers her mouth in shock. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 18.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: What is it? Barnum energetically leads them through a room filled wit famous figures. Many have been slightly damaged in transi

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: A wax figure! They’re all the rage in Europe now! Look -- there’s Napoleon! (waves in his face) Hello! And Marie Antoinette, with the sore throat! You can meet them all! The most famous people who every lived! Everyone knows they’re not real, but it doesn’t matter! People want to believe, so they do!

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Speaking of which... I brought this. Charity holds out something wrapped in a blanket. Barnum unwraps it. It is the driftwood mermaid from the beach. Barnum is touched. He looks up at Charity. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: What’s that? Barnum gently sets piece of wood into a display case.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: It’s a mermaid. Straight from Fiji!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: It looks like driftwood.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Only to the most literal-minded! He looks to Charity for support. Charity, however, looks around skeptically -- the room filled with a rather sorry collection: a pygmy skeleton, half-melted wax figures, et

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: I’m not sure people are going to pay to see a handful of wax dummies --

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Exactly! Which is why I also hired... Acrobats! He whistles and a FAMILY of elderly Romanians stumble on do a routine. Barnum beams as the girls look on in wonder Charity leaves, needing a moment. Barnum watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 19. 30 INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - A FEW MINUTES LATER 30 Barnum comes into the lobby to find Charity, fretting.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I know how it looks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Good. If you didn’t, I’d be worried.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: This is just the beginning...

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: How much did we put into this again?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: It’s complicated.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: -- how much?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Everything. Charity takes a moment to absorb that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: You're either a genius or a madman.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Or both. Off Barnum’s grin, we

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - A FEW WEEKS LATER A small MUSICAL BAND rehearsing in the corner. Not very w Barnum moves through the place trailed by Helen and Carol in their best dresses, as he makes sure everything is rea They approach ANNE WHEELER, the acrobat from the opening, doing a one-handed handstand on the raised palm of her brother W.D. (20, African-American, with a boxer’s build) The girls are transfixed. Anne sees them, and dismounts.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Barnum. Opening day jitters. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 32-34 35 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 20.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Please, call me P.T. Girls, this is Anne Wheeler, and her brother, W.D. The greatest acrobats in the entire world! Anne rolls her eyes at the hyperbole and smiles at the gi

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Maybe Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Okay, everyone, take your places! INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - LOBBY - A BIT LATER 31 Barnum marches across the festively decorated lobby, comp with a “GRAND OPENING” banner. He is trailed by Caroline Helen. A CASHIER, MR. O'MALLEY, gets ready to sell ticket The Band strikes up their best festive Opening Day music.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: All right, now! Is everyone ready?

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY, CAROLINE AND HELEN
dialogues.text: Ready! He reaches the front doors, takes one last look around, t throws them open grandly, his face filled with expectatio No one is there. Outside, on the street, ordinary life go on, ignoring them. Everyone deflates a bit. Except Barnum

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: No one cares...!

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: No, they do care. They just don’t know it yet. He picks up an old-fashioned megaphone, puts on his hat.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 32-34
dialogues.text: EXT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - DAY (CONTINUOUS) 35 Barnum comes out, sees a parade of grey PEOPLE, trudging through their daily grind. He starts hawking the PASSERSB

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: That's right, ladies and gentlemen! Step this way! You won’t believe your eyes! Through these doors are more mysteries and beguilements than have ever been assembled under one roof! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 36-37 38 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 21.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: No one pays attention. He tries again.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into megaphone) Right this way, folks! Be the first to see the wonders of the Barnum Museum! Come one, come all! See things you’ve never seen! Things you never imagined! He stops. Dozens of people walk past, ignoring the museum Then he notices Caroline and Helen, by the front door, watching him fail to draw a crowd. He turns, mind spinnin desperate not to fail again. He turns and takes stock of assets -- Anne, W.D., Charity, Caroline, Helen... ..-And O'Malley, the pudgy, earnest, fresh-off-the-boat I ticket seller. Barnum marches over to the ticket booth.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Malley. What are you doing? O’MALLEY At the moment, sir? Very little.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Exactly. Come out. I need your help. O'Malley exits the ticket booth, uncomfortable with Barnu attention. Barnum throws his arms over O’Malley’s shoulde

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here's what we’re going to do -- I’m out here trying to get as many people as possible to buy tickets to my museum. O’MALLEY And you want me to help.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: No. I want you to tell everyone they shouldn't buy tickets. O'Malley looks baffled. Barnum leads him into the museum.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me explain...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 36-37
dialogues.text: EXT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - DAY 38 Barnum and O’Malley step onto the street, nervous. People pass by without a second look. Barnum speaks sotto. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 22.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Okay. Let’s sell this. If things go wobbly, make a quick exit. Ready? O'Malley nods. Barnum lifts his megaphone, in barker mode

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come one, come all! See the wonders of the Barnum Museum! Step right up, folks! O'Malley takes a breath. Suddenly, he is an unhappy custo O’MALLEY Sir, I want my money back! You should be ashamed of this museum! Ashamed, I say! A few people are drawn by the ruckus. Barnum “confronts”

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Now see here, sir! You bought your ticket and saw the sights...! O'Malley, getting into it, goes big -- almost hysterical. O’MALLEY Oh, if only I hadn’t! If only I could un- see what my eyes have glimpsed! It’s unfit for decent people, what you have in there! Unfit for decent society! Look what you've done to my wife and children! Charity approaches, looking stricken, clutching Caroline Helen to her sides. The girls cover their faces and “weep

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: (Irish accent) Y’ should be ashamed of yourself, Barnum! It’s not fit for children and ladies!

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Maybe not for ladies, but what about you? O’MALLEY You can’t talk to my wife that way! He grabs Barnum. They tussle. Women SCREAM. A big crowd forms. Suddenly, a police WHISTLE. A Cop pushes his way through the crowd. (The same one who broke up the lottery

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Break it up! Break it up! What’s going on here? Who started this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 23.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pulls them apart. O’Malley turns and addresses the cro O’MALLEY This museum is unfit for decent society! No one should buy a ticket! No one!

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: You can’t tell these good people what to do! They can think for themselves! Make up their own minds! Isn’t that right, folks? The CROWD roars in agreement. Barnum’s got them with him.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Yes! Yeah! We can think for ourselves! O’MALLEY You are wicked, sir! Wicked! Barnum attacks him. They wrestle. The Cop pulls them apar

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: That’s it, Barnum! You’re under arrest! Barnum, scared, breaks away and sprints back into the mus The Cop puts a hand on his holster, and runs after him.

dialogues.speaker: COP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop right there! Stop or I’1l shoot! Barnum runs into the museum. The Cop follows. The crowd, watching it all agog, erupts in a HUBBUB. INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM —- CONTINUOUS Barnum runs in, stops. The Cop comes in and joins him. It immediately clear that they are, in fact, confederates.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Here we go! Stand back! He strikes a match, lights a small string of firecrackers Barnum tosses them on the floor, the first one POPS loudl EXT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - DAY From inside, a muffled POP. Another POP, POP, POP, anda SCREAM. The crowd surges forward. Everyone is now completely desperate to see what’s inside the museum. W.D leaps into action, waving the crowd toward the box office (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 24.

dialogues.speaker: W.D.
dialogues.text: This way, folks! See what’s inside! Have your money ready! Children half-price! O'Malley, Charity, Caroline and Helen stop acting and wat amazed, as the crowd surges in, all desperate to buy tick INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - NIGHT W.D. is seeing the last CUSTOMERS out the door. W.D. Thanks for coming, folks! Tell your friends! And come back soon! He closes the door. Charity opens the door to a back offi Barnum and the COP are kicked back, playing cards.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Are they gone?

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: (incredulous) You. Are. Shameless! Barnum grins, peels off a few bills, slips them to the Co

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming in, Tommy. Sorry about the short notice.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Any time, P.T. I always wanted to be an actor. Nice workin’ with ya, Charity! He tips his hat to her and exits. Barnum turns proudly.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: So... How many tickets did we sell?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: We don’t know!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: We ran out of tickets! Barnum couldn’t be happier. Charity looks at him -- both impressed and concerned. Barnum sees her look, and grins.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: They may not get exactly what they paid for, but they’re getting their money’s worth. 39  40 41 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 25.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - NIGHT (SEVERAL WEEKS LATER) Barnum, upbeat, sees out the last visitors of the day.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Have a good night! Come see us again! The visitors file out, looking only moderately impressed. Barnum shuts the doors behind them and allows his false c to fade. He heads back to where W.D. is counting the take W.D. Less than yesterday. Barnum nods. He plops into a chair -- edgy, his mind raci

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: The museum’s not working! There are things to see, but it doesn’t add up! People visit but they don’t come back! W.D. Why would they come back?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: (leaping up) Exactly! I want them happy when they walk out of here! Transformed! Open to possibilities again! All I’ve got now is a crummy museum! He sits again -- stewing, seething. W.D. cautiously avers W.D. Well... Maybe you could show ‘em something while they’re here. That’s the business you’re in, right? Showing? Barnum freezes -- his mind going a million miles an hour. snaps his fingers, jumps up, and paces like a caged tiger

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: You're right! I don’t need a stuffed lion, I need a real lion! Not a wax soldier, a real soldier! It needs to be an experience -- an event! -- with music and magic and death-defying feats! Something you'll want to see over and over! Not a museum but a show! Not just any show -- The greatest show anyone has ever seen! The greatest show on earth! 40 4l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 26. INT. BARNUM’S TENEMENT APARTMENT - BEDROOM - NIGHT 42 Barnum tucks Caroline in next to Helen, who’s already asl

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Will there be dancing girls?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Every show has dancing girls.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: What about acrobats?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Every show has acrobats. Or trained animals. Or daredevils...

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you have them all? A show with everything?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: That’s not a bad idea. A show with everything! But still... It’s just more of the same, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: But... What else is there?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I don’t know! I want performers you can’t see anywhere else. Someone who couldn’t possibly exist but there they are, right in front of you! A man with two heads! Or a giant, ten feet tall! Like you're walking into a dream! And when you walk out, you’re glad you were alive to see it!

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: What about Tom Thumb?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Tom Thumb?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: He’s a boy we read about in school. They say he’s the size of your thumb.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: (holds up his thumb) Tom Thumb. I like that. You should be doing my job. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF  42 43 44 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He leans down and kisses Caroline. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnum knocks on the door. A CRONE-LIKE WOMAN opens it an peers out, not saying a word.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Good day, Madam. I am looking for a Mr. Charles Sherwood Stratton.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Never heard of him. She starts to close the door. He stops her.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: That’s a funny thing to say about your own son. Her look confirms he’s right.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please, ma’am. You have no idea what I’ve gone through to find him. I have a proposal that could change his life. The woman, MRS. STRATTON, hesitates, not sure she underst what he said. Finally, she pulls the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnum sits in the main room, waiting. After a moment, CHARLES STRATTON enters the room. 25 inches, 20 pounds. H is a boy, but the same chromosomal glitch that affects hi growth also makes him look like a much older man. His mot turns away, clearly ashamed. But Barnum is delighted.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Hello. My name is Mr. P.T. Barnum. Barnum stands, realizes he’s way too tall, sits back down Stratton stares at the floor, guarded, defensive, tense.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: What you want with me?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I’m putting together a show. And I want you to star in it. A snort from Mrs. Stratton. Stratton looks up accusingly. A lifetime of alienation and ridicule has made him scrapp (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 28.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Why? So people can laugh at me?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: They're laughing anyway, kid. You might as well get paid. They are shocked. No one’s ever spoken so bluntly to them

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STRATTON
dialogues.text: Really, Mr. Barnum. You should be ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I was, Mrs. Stratton. For a long time. I was poor, and I was laughed at. I’ve been called a fool many times...

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Oh, please, you're breaking my heart! Barnum turns, facing down the tiny but glowering Stratton

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: ...But I don’t care about that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Good! Neither do I!

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Because we all have just one life, Mr. Stratton. One can wallow in self-pity...

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Thank you, I will! Goodbye, Mr. Barnum! Stratton exits, slamming the bedroom door. Barnum, it see has failed. The mother gently ushers Barnum to the door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STRATTON
dialogues.text: Leave us alone. Please. At the door, Barnum hesitates, noticing some TOY HORSES a SOLDIERS on the window sill. He picks one up, turns. He speaks out loud, conjuring a vision, selling a dream...

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Here is what I see, Mr. Stratton -- a soldier... Not just a soldier, a general! On horseback! Riding across the stage! With a sword, a gun! The most beautiful uniform ever made! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 29.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People will come from all over the world to see him ride and shoot and be a commander of men! I am creating a great spectacular, Mr. Stratton, and I want you to be my star! Silence. The back door CREAKS open. Stratton peeks in. Barnum can see him wavering. With fervent conviction:

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No one ever made a difference in this world by being like everyone else. You can come with me now, and live your dreams. Or stay here with your self-pity, and your mother. Beat. The door opens fully. Stratton stands, unguarded an vulnerable -- it’s like Barnum has looked into his soul.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you say, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: My name’s Charles.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: (grins) Not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: 45-46 OMITTED 45-46
dialogues.text: 47 EXT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - NIGHT 47 CLOSE ON -- A giant poster on the marquee features a draw of Stratton, in a general’s uniform, riding a gigantic ho

dialogues.speaker: GRAND OPENING
dialogues.text: CRANE DOWN to find a small CROWD, a few hundred customers filing down the sidewalk into the museum entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a nearby back alley, Barnum stands with Tom, helping h struggle into the jacket of a tiny military uniform.

dialogues.speaker: TOM THUMB
dialogues.text: This thing is itchy! Didn’t you say my uniform would be nice?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: For the audience! Not for you! Are these enough medals for a general? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 30. 48

dialogues.speaker: TOM THUMB
dialogues.text: How should I know? I’m eleven.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: And that’s the last time you ever say that. Because today you turn fifty-two. Let me hear you say it. How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM THUMB
dialogues.text: I'm fifty-two.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Right. Now do you need to use the bathroom before you go on? Tom shakes his head. Off screen, the CROWD ROARS at an pr opening act. Tom turns, nervous, starting to get cold fee

dialogues.speaker: TOM THUMB
dialogues.text: This was a mistake. I can’t do this!

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Sure you can! You have to!

dialogues.speaker: TOM THUMB
dialogues.text: (freaking out) No, this is crazy! They’11 know I’m faking! I’m not a General! Look at me! Barnum crouches down, grabs him, looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Listen to me... Listen! It doesn’t matter where you’re from anymore! What matters is where you’re going! You can choose who you want to be! All of us can, don’t you see?!!! When you ride out there on that horse, you will be a solider! A General! And you're going to be the tallest and bravest man in the room! (beat) Be proud of who you are, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: TOM THUMB
dialogues.text: Tom.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: (hesitates; points at Tom) Exactly! (they share a grin) Come on, kid. What do you say we give these people a show? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 49 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 31.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tom looks at Barnum -- scared, but willing to try. They’r jumping off this cliff together. INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - NIGHT 49 The audience is seated on benches now, right in the middl the main floor attractions. Anne, W.D., and other PERFORM do a few acrobatic tricks. Barnum hasn’t worked it out ye but we can see the idea of the circus starting to take sh

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, cads and crooks! For the first time ever in New York -- I give you untamed creatures of the wild! * The mayor has kindly sent his finest men * to protect us, should one of you do something to upset the animals -- He tips his hat to a few POLICEMAN. Then he nods to W.D., who stands in the back with a TRAINER and two BEARS. W.D. Go! The trainer enters the performing circle, coaxing the bea who walk on hind legs, to YELLS OF DELIGHT from the crowd Helen sits on Caroline’s lap, laughing and applauding lou Barnum nods to W.D., who slides open a FREIGHT DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: And now, for our final attraction -- They say good things come in small packages. Ladies and gentlemen -- the bravest, fiercest, wildest, most dangerous soldier who ever lived--...! +e * HF The expectant crowd turns. There are GASPS as General Tom Thumb rides out on a LITTLE PONY.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- please make way for General Tom Thumb! The crowd roars as Tom Thumb rides his pony across the fu length of the museum, firing his gun. He seems transforme cocky and mischievous, and full of joy. As is the audienc Barnum, thrilled, takes a seat next to Charity. She smile taking in the laughter and delight around them. *

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you were trying to do, but I’m pretty sure you’re doing it. * Barnum smiles at his wife, elated by the energy in the ro  50 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An after-show party. Tom Thumb entertains the others by drinking from a bottle while balancing on W.D.’s out- stretched hand. Barnum plucks the bottle from his hand, replaces it with a glass of milk, to much LAUGHTER. Barnum, in high spirits, downs a drink at the bar with An then turns to see SAM ROTH, a grumpy newspaperman who wat the antics with opprobrium. Roth lifts his glass to Barnu

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: Impressive, Mr. Barnum.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. And you are?

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: Sam Roth.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: From the Tribune! You got my letter! (claps his shoulder) It’s an honor, sir! How much do I have to pay you to write a good review for us?

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: I don’t know if you have that much money.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: You might be surprised, Mr. Roth.

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: Yes, well... No one ever went broke underestimating the intelligence of the American public. Your show is proof of that. Though even the public has it’s limits, I hope... Barnum is thrown by this.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I think perhaps you missed the point --

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: -- Really? Was there a subtext to the prancing dwarf that went over my head?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: You're over-thinking it. We aim to show people the wonders of the world... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 51 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 33.

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: Wonders? Is that what you call freaks being paraded for entertainment?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Sir, the man you are calling a freak is my colleague, and my friend...

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: Oh, is that how you treat your friends? Putting them on display for everyone to gawk at? I hate to waste ink on this atrocity, but I have a duty to warn the public. And when I’m finished, I hope you will be finished as well. Roth finishes his drink and departs, leaving Barnum worri INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - DAY 51 Morning. Barnum, Charity, W.D., Anne, and Tom sit at a ta by the stage, as Charity finishes reading Roth’s review.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: ",..insulting, degrading, and perhaps just shy of criminal, P.T. Barnum’s show is the singularly most unpleasant evening I have spent in years, calling to mind the most primitive aspects of the Roman Circuses of yore.” She stops -- it’s too painful to go on. Uneasy silence. Barnum takes the review and scans it, thinking fiercely.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Phin... I’m so sorry. Barnum looks up -- eyes shining, seemingly elated.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: It’s fantastic. He leaps up, rips out the review and hands it to W.D.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go to the Tribune and buy a half-page ad. Tell them to reprint the entire review, word for word. Everyone is stunned. This is borderline insanity.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: He called you The Prince Of Humbug. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 34.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Humbug is merely the time-honored use of hyperbole to create excitement and joy.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Humbug is a lie, dear.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: What’s important is: we made page one. (to W.D.) And tell them I’1l give half-price tickets to anyone who brings in a review. (off their looks) When other papers see people rushing to buy the Tribune, they’ll review us too. W.D. starts for the door, then turns back to Barnum. W.D. You sure, Mr. B.? The whole city will read this by dinner time. Barnum, hesitates, doubting his bravado for a second. * Charity, clocking it, comes to his rescue.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Of course he’s sure. He was born sure. W.D. nods and leaves. Barnum smiles at his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - DAY (WEEKS LATER) The line outside the museum is now three times longer. We FOLLOWING a WOMAN who pushes her way thru the crowd, her UNSEEN by us. People react as she passes. As she approach W.D. in the box office window, he looks up. His jaw drops + eH ANGLE -- LETTIE LUTZ, mid-30s, has dark hair, strong plea features, and a FULL BEARD. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LETTIE
dialogues.text: I'd like to see Mr. Barnum. INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM, BACKSTAGE - DAY W.D. leads Lettie in. Barnum is busy helping O’CLANCY, th Irish Giant, onto stilts. Humbug -- behind the scenes. * Nearby, Tom Thumbs sits, strumming on a ukulele, while an enormously fat man, the LORD OF LEEDS, plucks out a simpl tune on a banjo (the melody to COME ALIVE). Opposite Barn TWO MEN sit on a sofa, their backs to us. In the backgrou acrobats and jugglers casually practice their routines. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 35.

dialogues.speaker: W.D.
dialogues.text: Excuse me, P.T., this lady -- She barrels forward.

dialogues.speaker: LETTIE
dialogues.text: Lettie Lutz. Nice to meet you. Let me get to the point, Mr. Barnum. I’ve never * been one for self-pity or embarrassment. So when I read in the paper about folks * paying good money to see a short man, a tall man and a fat man, I thought -- Why * should they be the only ones making out? Heck, I’m as weird as any of ‘em. Barnum stands, clearly charmed.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Weird isn’t the word I'd use, Miss Lutz. More like rare, blessed... Beautiful. Lettie beams, no one has ever spoken to her like this.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Allow me to introduce you. O’Clancy, the Irish Giant. Nine feet tall...! O’ CLANCY .--With two feet of help.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: The famous Tom Thumb. Our biggest star, the Lord of Leeds. And my new friends. Chang, and Eng. Of Siam. Smiles and greetings. The seated men stand and turn. Meet CHANG and ENG, the legendary Siamese twins, 40. Each bows and extends a courtly hand. Lettie lets out a laugh, take both their hands. This place already feels like home.

dialogues.speaker: LETTIE
dialogues.text: Oh fellas... I think you got me beat. MUSIC starts under... *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK CUTS -- Posters are rolled up on the side of the Mu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: advertising the wondrous attractions inside with Barnum h -- “TALLEST MAN ALIVE! O’CLANCY, THE IRISH GIANT!” * -— “LETTIE LUTZ! AMERICA’S BEARDED WOMAN!” -- “THE LORD OF LEEDS! HEAVIEST MAN ON EARTH!” *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 55 56 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 36. EXT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - DAY 54 The line is now around the block. W.D. supervises more TI TAKERS. A sign: “BY POPULAR DEMAND, SECOND SHOW TONIGHT.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As CUSTOMERS move quietly through the doors, there’s more sense of drudgery than excitement -- people with hard liv Barnum walks down the line, eyeing the Customers in line.

dialogues.speaker: WAS TOLD TO HIDE AWAY
dialogues.text: INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - EVENING 55 Barnum walks “backstage,” singing as he passes all of the performers preparing to go on; Chang and Eng dressing together, Anne stretching, Lettie combing her beard. He * stops by each one -- helping them get ready for the show, trading grins and supportive smiles, keeping everyone hap

dialogues.speaker: ANYTHING YOU WANT TO BE, IT'S TIME TO LET 'EM SEE
dialogues.text: INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - NIGHT 56 The cavernous first floor has been transformed, dominated a circle of tiered BLEACHERS surrounding a massive STAGE. Barnum stands alone, singing to the crowd, illuminated by carbon lamp and candle footlights.

dialogues.speaker: AND THE WORLD BECOMES A FANTASY
dialogues.text: (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 37.

dialogues.speaker: AND YOU'RE MORE THAN YOU COULD EVER BE
dialogues.text: ‘CAUSE YOU'RE DREAMIN' WITH YOUR EYES WIDE OPEN

dialogues.speaker: TO THE WORLD THAT WE WERE LIVIN' IN
dialogues.text: ‘CAUSE WE'RE DREAMIN' WITH OUR EYES WIDE OPEN

dialogues.speaker: SO COME ALIVE
dialogues.text: In the wings, Lettie stands in a sequined gown, suddenly unsure of herself. She makes eye contact with Barnum, who offers a warm, reassuring smile. She will be safe here. H gestures to the stage. She smiles, and steps into the lig Then Barnum encourages a PARADE of ODDITIES to take the stage. Those who were once hidden in the shadows now step into the spotlight, and feel accepted for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: BUT NOW THEY'RE FLIPPIN', FALLIN', HEAR
dialogues.text: ‘EM CALLIN' OUT YOUR NAME LETTIE/W.D.

dialogues.speaker: YOU'RE ELECTRIFIED
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 57 58 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 38.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: People gasp as they suddenly see Anne circling in a wide above their heads. Children point and laugh as circus performers tumble into each other on the stage. Then a massive LION enters, led by a colorfully dressed LION TAM It is a show of astonishments, almost too much to take in In the wings, Barnum helps Tom Thumb onto his pony, ready him for his big entrance. Then Barnum turns. Eunice the * elephant is there, towering over them. Barnum turns back, looks at Tom thumb. They make eye contact. Uh oh. * JUMP TO: Eunice the elephant enters the ring, with Tom Th riding on top, causing the place to explode. We realize w are watching the birth of the circus as we know it.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 57
dialogues.text: INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - DAY 58* Barnum watches the Oddities lined up to take a bow. Letti comes and pulls him from the wings out onto the stage. Sh places a tin CROWN on his head. It reads: “PRINCE OF HUMB Barnum plays to the joke, proudly strutting across the st In the audience, Helen shouts out to Charity and Caroline

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: What’s humbug?

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: They say it’s fakery. Trickery. Flim- * flam.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: No! It’s magic! * The whole circus unites behind the smiling, tin-crowned * Barnum. It is a joyous, exuberant moment. *

dialogues.speaker: COME ONE, COME ALL
dialogues.text: Come IN, COME ON! *

dialogues.speaker: TO ANYONE WHO'S SEARCHING FOR A WAY TO BREAK FREE
dialogues.text: 59 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 39. EXT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - NIGHT 59* People spill out in the street after a show -- elated, ab with delight, and transformed by the experience. They are literally grabbing their friends and pulling them toward box office -- you gotta see this! Hawkers sell merchandis children buy Tom Thumb DOLLS, Eunice the Elephant LOLLIPO Barnum surveys the people as they exit. He sees Sam Roth skulking in the alley and flashes a triumphant smile at h

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: Tell me, Barnum. Does it bother you that what you’re selling is fake? Barnum steps onto the sidewalk. Roth steps out as well no so the two men are facing off just a few feet apart.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Do those smiles seem fake? Or the applause? It doesn’t matter where it comes from. The joy is real.

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: So now you’re a philanthropist?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I’m an entertainer.

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: The prince of Humbug.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Hyperbole isn’t the worst crime, Mr. Roth. Men suffer more from imagining too little than too much.

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: Ah -- the creed of a true fraud.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: There’s nothing sadder than a cynic, except perhaps a cynic with a pen.

dialogues.speaker: ROTH
dialogues.text: A philosopher too! Please, sir, don’t add pretension to your list of sins.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Mr. Roth -- when is the last time you smiled? Or had a good laugh? A real one? The simplicity of the question silences Roth. Barnum smil (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 60 The Greatest Showman On Earth

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A joyless reporter covering the theater. Now who’s the fraud? Roth waves him off and starts to leave. Barnum points to the marquee.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By the way, Roth, That word you used to describe my show -- 4/20/15 Draft ‘AMERICAN MUSEUM’ 40. 59 Barnum stops him. has been painted over. The new sign reads: ‘P.T. BARNUM’S CIRCUS.’ Roth lets of the street and calls after him defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It has a nice ring to it. out a snort, leaves. Barnum steps into the middle

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m still here, Roth! I’m still here! INT. BARNUM’'S MUSEUM - DAY (ANOTHER DAY) The grand finale, every act on stage.

dialogues.speaker: AND YOU'RE MORE THAN YOU COULD EVER BE
dialogues.text: Barnum beams as he takes in the delirium in the audience, feeling as much at home with the Oddities as he has felt anywhere in his lif ‘CAUSE YOU'RE DREAMIN' WITH YOUR EYES WIDE OPEN

dialogues.speaker: TO THE WORLD THAT WE WERE LIVIN'
dialogues.text: ‘CAUSE WE'RE DREAMIN' WITH OUR EYES WIDE OPEN

dialogues.speaker: COULD EVER BE
dialogues.text: ‘CAUSE WE'RE DREAMIN' WITH

dialogues.speaker: IN
dialogues.text: ‘CAUSE WE'RE DREAMIN' WITH OUR EYES WIDE OPEN ‘CAUSE WE'RE DREAMIN' WITH OUR EYES WIDE OPEN

dialogues.speaker: SO COME ALIVE
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 62 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 41.

dialogues.speaker: END SONG.
dialogues.text: Over the sounds of enthusiastic APPLAUSE we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful tree-lined street. Barnum steps out of a ZEBR DRAWN CARRIAGE, then helps a blindfolded Charity out. Hel and Caroline jump out after them. Time has passed -- they all better-dressed and more polished than they used to be

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Right this way, m’lady.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: I’m going to break my neck. Barnum removes the scarf. Charity is stunned to see the s MANSION that she and Barnum broke into as children.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is the same--...?!

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: It is. In the gated backyard, there is an actual GIRAFFE grazing

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Oh, Phin. Can we afford this?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Of course. And even if we couldn’t, it’s an investment. Land is the one thing they’re not making any more of. (to Helen) I think there’s something on the porch for you. Helen looks and sees a GIANT WOODEN DOLLHOUSE on the porc She shrieks happily and runs up to claim it. They come up the stairs behind her. Barnum opens the door. He grabs a small WHITE BOX from the foyer, turns to Caroline.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Something for you too. She opens the box and pulls out a PAIR OF BALLET SLIPPERS She looks up at him -- it’s what she’s always wanted.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And, funny enough, there’s a ballet school just down the street. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 42.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Caroline jumps for joy and kisses him, then runs to catch to Helen, who’s already inside the house and headed upsta

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your parents still live nearby, don’t they?

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Phin. If I didn’t know you better, I might wonder if you bought this house to rub my parents’ noses in your success.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: OUR success. And of course not. It’s true that I’ve accomplished everything your father said I never would --

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Yes... But you know, to them, house or no house, you’ll always be a bum from the south side.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Yes, but now I’m a bum with a huge house they have to walk past every Sunday. She laughs. He sweeps her up in his arms and carries her the steps and across the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful! She runs upstairs to look around. Barnum stands at the fo of the stairs watching happily as the members of his fami appear and disappear from rooms. Finally Charity slides d the banister -- a little circus in her -- and lands in Barnum’s arms. They do a little dance around the room.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: It took twenty years longer than I planned, but... Welcome home, Charity. He dips her back. They kiss. Brings her up again.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: And the giraffe is not staying.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Right.  64 65 66 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline sits at the foot of the stairs, putting on her ballet shoes. She practices a few motions - she has clear already begun her classes. MUSIC: Orchestral version of “A Million Dreams.” Caroline dances around the foyer, confidence growing. She disappears around the staircase and when she emerges she TWO YEARS OLDER, dressed in a tutu. The lights go down - she is lit by a single spotlight as dances with skill and maturity. We are no longer in Barnu mansion, but on a dark stage. As Caroline finishes her dance, she is joined by six other ballerinas. They bow to round of applause. We DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reception for students and parents, where the upper cru gather to turn their daughters into swans. Barnum and Cha stroll among the other guests. He is upbeat, ebullient.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Remember when we couldn’t afford ballet slippers? And now -- look at this. Barnum tips his hat to another couple, MR. and MRS. WINTH

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop! Lovely recital, don’t you think? They barely nod to him as they pass. Charity shakes her h

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Why do you still bother?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I know I shouldn’t. I just love the look on their faces when I do. He watches the Winthrops go join a small crowd encircling handsome, jaded young man, PHILLIP CARLYLE. Barnum frowns

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who is that man?

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Phillip Carlyle? His new play is a hit on Broadway. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 44,

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Play, huh? Pfff! You pay good money to watch people stand around and talk for two hours! They call me a con man! But as he watches others flock around Phillip, he can see social power of artistic success. Barnum suddenly makes a beeline, joining the small crowd. Charity follows. As he arrives, the Winthrops are begging Phillip for a favor.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WINTHROP
dialogues.text: .+.We know it’s sold out, but if you could find us two tickets for Sunday...

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. I’11 see what I can do. Excuse me. He slips off -- louche, bored by the attention. The Winth know they've been dissed. They look disappointed. Barnum, witnessing this, can’t help himself. He steps up, genuine

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: You know, if you ever want to take in the circus, we'd love to have you. As my guest, of course. Bring the family --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Thank you just the same, Mr. Barnum. They turn on their heels and walk off, with another COUPL Barely out of hearing, the Winthrops lean into each other

dialogues.speaker: MR. WINTHROP
dialogues.text: My God, what was that smell?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Peanuts. They and the other Couple laugh. A nearby group of Baller SNICKER, and turn, parting to reveal... Caroline, among t with the Winthrop’s daughter MARY. Caroline’s eyes well u but she forces a smile. The Winthrops stop short, coverin

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WINTHROP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh hello, girls! Caroline, dear, I believe your parents are looking for you. RACK FOCUS ACROSS the room to see Barnum staring darkly. has witnessed the entire exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charity and Helen walk ahead while Barnum strolls with Caroline, who is withdrawn and a bit down.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I was so proud of you tonight, Caroline. You were amazing up there.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: I really wasn’t. (then) I’ve actually decided to quit the ballet.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Quit?! why?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: I started too late. I’11 never catch up. I’m just not good enough.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Not good enough?! You were the best dancer on that stage! Caroline looks away, too old to buy into his hype.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: What would you know about it?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: You think I can’t spot talent?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: How many ballets have you seen in your life?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Not everything’s like the circus, you know. Ballet takes years of hard work. (pointed, sharp) You can’t just fake it. She runs off, bounding up the steps ahead of Charity and Helen. We hold on Barnum, who looks stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charity moves in and out of the room, preparing for bed. Barnum is slumped in a chair, sad and worried. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 46.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: It'd be a shame if she quit. She just feels out of place with the other girls.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: I should hope so. I’ve never seen so many entitled little prima donnas.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Those prima donnas are the most important thing in the world to her right now. She just wants to fit in. Charity gives him a look. This is about more than Carolin

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: People like the Winthrops will never accept us, Phin. If they did, they’d have to stop judging. And then they might actually have to do something with their lives.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I don’t want it for me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: Caroline will be fine. Eventually.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: She’s embarrassed by me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: She’s a teenager. Charity puts her arms around him, smiles. But he won’t be assuaged. He shakes his head -- this cuts too deep.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: No. I want her to be proud of who she is. Her family. Proud of me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY
dialogues.text: She is proud of you. In her way. He looks at her -- that seals it. She gazes at him, worri

dialogues.speaker: CHARITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Phineas...? PRELAP: Sound of polite applause.  69 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnum exits, pulling on his coat, and spots Phillip Carl standing under the marquis, beside a poster advertising t play that just ended: “THE DRUNKARD or THE FALLEN SAVED,” temperance movement drama that was the snob hit of 1857. He glances around at the sober-faced survivors of his pla

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Carlyle? I believe you produced this play --

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: Yes, and I apologize. Refunds are available at the box office.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: (offers his hand) P.T. Barnum.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: (shakes it vigorously) From the circus? I’m a great admirer of what you do, Mr. Barnum.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Oh come now --

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: I’m serious. People leave your shows transformed, or at least a good deal happier than when they came in. Which is more than I can say for my play. Can the evils of alcohol be the theme, plot, and moral all at the same time?

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Yet you have no trouble selling tickets.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: My audience believes it makes them sophisticated. I exploit that pretension, and everyone wins. Except art, of course. Art takes a bit of a beating.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I don’t suppose I could buy you a drink. That is, unless you don’t -- 47. 69 He gestures to a PHOTOGRAPH of the abstemious Mr. Cribbs the play. Phillip takes a flask from his vest pocket. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 70 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 48.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: How do you think I get through this play every night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fancy room, almost empty at this late hour. A lone pian player plays. They are a few rounds in. Barnum is low-key but he’s in full sell-mode -- passionate, a true believer

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: If we present legitimate entertainments, we can expand our appeal. Bring in the carriage trade. Go after the high-brows.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: Funny, you want to attract the snobs and I’ve spent my entire life wishing to get away from them. They are suffocating. He downs his drink, feeling vaguely sorry for himself. Barnum smiles, leans back.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: So, come join the circus! You clearly have a flair for show business.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: “Show business”?! I’ve never heard that term before!

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Because I just invented it. (smiles) And you were there!

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: I like it. But I’m still not clear on what you think I can do for you. The last few drinkers make their exit, leaving Barnum and Phillip alone with the piano player.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Teach me how to appeal to the snobs, as you call them. Make it fashionable. Sophisticated. Ennobling. Shakespeare, and all that. Exploit their pretensions.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: You’ve created this wonderful show and now you want to pervert it with culture? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 49.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Anything to fill seats, Mr. Carlyle! And I‘'1l teach you everything I know about the circus. Phillip grins at Barnum -- he really likes him. However.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: I appreciate the offer, Mr. Barnum. But such an association could, at the very least, cost me my inheritance. Barnum waves dismissively -- cheerful and high-spirited.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Oh, it’d cost you a lot more than that! Your inheritance, your reputation! Your place in society! Why, people would look at you the same way they look at me!

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: (sheepish) No offense.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: None taken! The pianist hits a chord, and Barnum starts to sing.

dialogues.speaker: OUT OF THE DRUDGERY AND WALLS YOU KEEP IN
dialogues.text: ‘CAUSE YOU CAN DO LIKE YOU DO

dialogues.speaker: WITH THIS UPTOWN PART I GET TO PLAY
dialogues.text: ‘CAUSE I GOT WHAT I NEED

dialogues.speaker: THEY'RE LAUGHIN' ON THE OTHER SIDE
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 50.

dialogues.speaker: BUT I GUESS I'LL LEAVE IT UP TO YOU...
dialogues.text: Barnum turns and walks away from Phillip. Over his should he points back to Phillip’s flask and casually says:

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, you might not have to drink so much if you actually enjoyed your life. Phillip looks down at the flask in his hand, realizing Ba is right. He’s won over, but won’t yet admit it. Barnum a Phillip end up on opposite sides of the piano, negotiatin

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: WELL IT’S INTRIGUING BUT IT’S GONNA COST

dialogues.speaker: ME GREATLY
dialogues.text: WHAT’S MY PERCENTAGE OF THE MONEY THAT

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: (laughs, sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: TWELVE
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 71 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 51.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: I’LL DO NINE.

dialogues.speaker: TEN
dialogues.text: Barnum considers it, then nods. Phillip extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir. You have yourself a junior partner. Barnum gives the hand a wry look, but doesn’t shake it. H pours himself a drink, shoves a bottle in Phillip’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: What I have is an over-compensated apprentice. They both toss back a last drink (Phillip from the bottle Then turn and walk out of the club, arm in arm. END SONG. INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM, BACKSTAGE - NIGHT Barnum enters and walks Phillip through the large backsta 70 71 space. It’s surreal. Oddities, acrobats, jugglers, animal contortionists -- Phillip takes it all in. Barnum welcome him into the fold with an exuberant, well-practiced patte

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Welcome to the circus, Mr. Carlyle! The most dangerous collection of wild, feral animals ever assembled under one roof! (grins) And that’s just the performers. (pointing) We've got big, we’ve got small, we've got bearded, we've got tall! But there’s one thing that unites all of them! Tom Thumb, playing cards with O’Clancy the Giant, looks u

dialogues.speaker: TOM THUMB
dialogues.text: We're underpaid.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: We are free here. To be ourselves. We are vagabonds! Gypsies! Bohemians! Pirates! Let the rest of the world be dull and grey! Let the rest of the world spend their days in drudgery and grub-work! We are here as prophets of wonder and joy! Fun is our work, and our work is fun! Come on, I'll show you how it’s done...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 The Greatest Showman On Earth 4/20/15 Draft 52. INT. BARNUM’S MUSEUM - NIGHT They step off a ladder, onto a catwalk above the last row bleachers. From here, you can see everything. The vast space is dark, though you can HEAR a packed hous SPOTLIGHTS sweep the room, tracking an acrobatic act. Phillip leans forward to see what's going on, when... .+.-The CROWD beneath them parts, and Anne comes swinging from below, arms free. Her arc ends almost face to face w Phillip. Then gravity whips her back in the other directi Phillip turns to Barnum. Barnum grins.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: Who was that? LATER -- As another act, a daredevil HORSE RIDER, takes o circling the ring, Anne disengages from her ribbons with W.D.’s help. Barnum steps up with Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: Miss Anne Wheeler? I’d like to introduce my newest hire, Mr. Phillip Carlyle. Anne takes in Phillip with her eyes, then shakes his hand

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: And what’s your act, Mr. Carlyle?

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: I don’t have an act --

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Everyone’s got an act. Instant chemistry. Anne, freed from her ribbons, smiles, flirty, and walks off. Phillip, smitten, turns to check o Anne.
